awd_titl_txt: Removal of time and fidelity constraints in MALDI-MS imaging of proteins in tissue
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Franco Basile and his group at the University of Wyoming are working to develop new means of determining the composition and distribution of proteins in biological samples, employing the powerful analytical tools of mass spectrometry (MS).  Specifically, the Basile group is developing new means of using MS to form an image of the location of specific (bio)chemicals on biological samples, including animal or plant tissue.  These tools can be used widely in investigations of fundamental biology, biomedical research, renewable energy (biofuels) and bio-inspired materials, all areas that benefit society.  Students involved receive broad, interdisciplinary training, preparing them for careers in a range of disciplines in industry and academia.  The project is also fostering collaborative research within the University of Wyoming, and involving faculty and students from neighboring institutions (including community colleges) and others in the broader MS-imaging scientific community.

The Basile team is developing a rapid (seconds) and solvent-free method to thermally digest and decompose proteins in biological samples.  This represents a significant improvement over current methodologies, which require time-consuming (4h to overnight) digestion of proteins with expensive and difficult-to-use enzymes in solution.  The non-enzymatic and solvent-free approach for on-tissue protein digestion is not only ~500 times faster than traditional enzymatic digestion, but also provides more control over the area of the tissue that is analyzed.  The new method utilizes well-characterized thermal protein decomposition reactions that were discovered and developed in the Basile laboratory over the last 10 years.  Potential applications span a wide range of disciplines, broadening the training received by participating students.

Project outcome

The Basile research group at the University of Wyoming developed a rapid reagentless approach to cleave (i.e., digest) large molecular weight proteins into smaller peptides. The development of rapid protein digestion methods directly benefits the field of mass spectrometry-based proteomics, as this step in the sample preparation workflow is often the rate limiting step in the entire measurement. The protein digestion step is performed as the analysis of smaller peptides is more feasible and the resulting data easier to interpret than when analyzing intact proteins via Mass Spectrometry (MS). The rapid and reagentless protein digestion method developed is based on the thermal degradation of proteins at atmospheric conditions. Upon heating proteins to temperatures near 250 ?C for 30 seconds, bond-breaking reactions are induced at the amino acids aspartic acid and cysteine within the protein sequence. In addition, several non-specific side reactions are also induced like dehydration, deamination and condensation reactions.

This rapid protein thermal-digestion method has been adapted for imaging-Mass Spectrometry (IMS), a molecular imaging technique. The thermal digestion process is a major step in simplifying and increasing the sample preparation step throughput. Comparison of the protein thermal digestion with standard enzyme-based digestion protocols yielded analogous images for brain putative proteins spatial distributions (Figure 1). More importantly, the thermal degradation protein digestion step was performed in 45 seconds, while the trypsin digestion step took over 2 hours of digestion time.

The ability to perform tissue digestion in a matter of seconds (rather than hours) is expected to improve sample throughput in MS-based proteomics, impacting research in areas of molecular biology, human health, ecology, zoology/physiology, and biology. Because of the complex nature of the thermal digestion reactions (i.e., side reactions), protein identification remains a challenge with this technique. However, the thermal digestion technique can be applied in areas where the rapid detection of specific biomarkers is needed, as in clinical diagnosis or rapid microbial detection.

Intellectual Merit

The discovery of thermally induced cleavages of peptide bonds at specific amino acids in the protein sequence opened opportunities to apply this phenomenon to mass spectrometry-based proteomics. In particular, our laboratory developed several approaches to induce thermal cleavages on biological tissues in a matter of seconds to minutes: photo-plasmonic induce heating, convection heating and radiative heating. For high sample throughput and rapid thermal digestion of the entire tissue section, a radiative heating apparatus was constructed in collaboration with the Chemical Engineering Department at the University of Wyoming. This heating device allowed for the efficient and reproducible thermal digestion of biological surfaces. Thermal digestion parameters were optimized for broad digestion efficiency across a wide range of protein molecular weights. Most important, the reagentless nature of this digestion approach removed the chances of analyte delocalization during sample preparation, thus increasing the spatial fidelity of the obtained molecular image.

Additionally, the implementation of a MALDESI source with a quadrupole-Orbitrap-MS system enabled us to perform imaging-MS measurements of lipid species at high mass and spatial resolutions. In a collaborative work with the department of Zoology and Physiology at the University of Wyoming, we have developed a method to reproducibly image lipid species in entire axial sections of bees (Figure 2). This capability is being used to study the bee metabolic responses due to climate stressors.

Broader Impact

The research work enabled by this NSF grant led to the development of imaging-MS tools in our lab and thus has greatly impacted our base knowledge and research capabilities. Specifically, our lab constructed a MALDESI source for increased mass and spatial resolution measurements, and incorporated cheminformatic tools for data analysis and visualization (Cardinal for PCA and PLS-DA of imaging-MS data; MetaSpace2020.eu for metabolite annotation of imaging-MS data). This has allowed our laboratory to apply imaging-MS techniques for the detection of lipid species in areas in Zoology (e.g., the study of bees? metabolism) and physiology/medicine (Alzheimer?s disease). The interdisciplinary nature of the project enabled the training of several graduate and undergraduate students from the chemistry, chemical engineering, and zoology departments. Work funded by this grant has been disseminated at the annual Mass Spectrometry conferences (ASMS 2018 and 2022) and the imaging-MS society (OurCon 2018).
